How does a researcher know when to use a qualitative approach and when to use a quantitative approach to a study? Is one approach really better than the other?
 
A choice between research methods rests fundamentally on a set of decisions about the questions a researcher wants to answer and the practicality of gathering the kind of data that will answer those questions. In this first part, we will explore the differences between the different research traditions. 

* Compare and contrast the qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods traditions to research design in public health
* Select an appropriate sampling strategy based on study design
* Summarize the key ethical considerations when engaging in human subjects research

Throughout this module we will use real-world examples and you will take on the role of the lead researcher.
This issue raises multiple research questions that could guide the intervention design, so you decide to review the existing data before formulating your research questions.

According to recent data from the Brooklynville Department of Health, the racial and ethnic disparities reported at the national level are also seen in the Brooklynville community. Black and Hispanic youth in Brooklynville account for a disproportionate number of new HIV diagnoses. In 2010, Black and Hispanic youth represented close to 75% of new HIV cases. The numbers also show that Brooklynville has a disproportionate number of HIV and AIDS cases in youth, compared to the rest of the United States. For example, although youth between the ages of 13 and 24 represent only 3% of the population, they account for roughly 14% of AIDS cases in Brooklynville.

These statistics concern you. Additionally, you conclude after reviewing the literature that most of the evidence-based interventions reported appear to be focused on HIV-prevention; few studies provide guidance on the kind of interventions that are effective for youth once they are diagnosed.

How is our right to know balanced against the participants’ right to privacy, dignity, and self-determination?  - Miles and Huberman

The definition of a human subject is “a living individual about whom an investigator (whether professional or student) conducting research obtains data through intervention or interaction with the individual, or identifiable private information.” Private information can include names, addresses, or cell phone numbers.

The nature of ethical problems in qualitative research is different compared to problems in quantitative research. For example, potential ethical conflicts could arise when considering how a researcher gains access to a community group, the effects the researcher may have on participants, and the subjective biases that may arise during data collection.
As a reminder, the question guiding our research is:

One of the primary reasons you determined that a qualitative study was right for your team’s investigation is because you know that qualitative methods allow researchers to understand the processes by which events and actions take place. 

A major strength of qualitative studies is their ability to get at the processes that lead to behaviors or outcomes, processes that survey research is often very poor at identifying.

###Key features of Qualitative Research###

1. **Generates a narrative**: Typically, qualitative research generates text or narrative (i.e., non-numerical) data that requires interpretative analysis. Text or narrative data can be come from a variety of sources including individual interviews, focus groups, or written responses from open-ended questions on a survey. Analyzing and interpreting textual data is an iterative process that begins during data collection and often continues throughout the later phases of the study.
2. **Direct contact with participants**: During data collection researchers will engage with research participants. Methods like in-depth interviews or focus groups whereby the researcher is the instrument of data collection provide the study participants with an opportunity to express their thoughts and feelings in their own words, to a skilled researcher who is attentive and actively listening. 
3. **Design flexibility**: Design flexibility allows researchers to adapt the research design as situations change or pursue new paths of discovery as they emerge. For example, during data collection you may reach “saturation” or a point when you are no longer hearing or seeing new information from your young respondents. Unlike quantitative researchers who wait until the end of the study to analyze their data, qualitative researchers often analyze their data throughout the study. The design flexibility inherent in qualitative designs allows you to pose new questions or follow up on previously unconsidered topics that your respondents might introduce during data collection. 

 But, is there only one way to approach qualitative research?

Qualitative research is often discussed as if it were one approach. However, qualitative research comes in many different varieties, or traditions:

1. Phenomenology
2. Ethnography
3. Grounded theory
4. Biography/narrative
5. Case study

The team decides to discuss three of the most common traditions and approaches used in the public health.

An exhaustive review of qualitative research traditions is beyond the scope of this module, however interested investigators may examine [Cresswell (2004)](http://www.amazon.com/Qualitative-Inquiry-Research-Design-Traditions/dp/0761901442) for a detailed discussion.

Phenomenology is the study of structures of consciousness as experienced from the first-person point of view. Studies developed in the phenomenological tradition are “directed to the participant’s experiences, feelings, beliefs and convictions about the theme in question” (Welman & Kruger, 1999, p. 196). Typically, the researcher reduces data gathered as lengthy interviews describing the shared experiences of several informants to a central meaning, or “essence” of the experience (McCaslin & Scott, 2003).

A qualitative project designed in a phenomenological tradition might pose questions like:

* What are the lived experiences of individuals in a given community?
* How does “stigma” impact the life of young people living with HIV? 
* What meanings do young people attach to an HIV diagnosis? 
* How do HIV-positive young people experience disclosure to their parents and sexual partners?

Ethnography is the study of cultures through close observation, reading, and interpretation. Ethnographic researchers work “in the field,” in the culture  they are studying. The activities they conduct are also often called fieldwork. Ethnographic researchers learn how to recognize traits that make up a culture and how to describe it to others; through direct and close participant observation researchers observe the differences between participants’ subjective reporting of what they believe and what they do (Creswell 1997).

A qualitative study designed from an ethnographic perspective might ask questions such as:

* What are the meanings that guide behavior?
* How is sexual desire is organized and interpreted in the lives of HIV-positive young women?
* What are the norms that guide risk behavior among homeless HIV-positive youth?

Grounded theory is a qualitative approach to generating and developing a theory from data that the researcher collects. As much as possible, the researcher should set aside theoretical ideas or notions so that the analytic, substantive theory can emerge. The primary outcome of this approach is a theory with specific components: a central phenomenon, causal conditions, strategies, conditions and context, and consequences (Corbin and Strauss 1990).

A qualitative study designed using a grounded theory approach might pose questions such as:
* What are the core social processes within a given social situation?
* What are the dynamics of hope and despair among young men who receive an HIV diagnosis? 
* How do HIV-positive youth manage their interacting illness symptoms, medication side effects, and treatment adherence choices?

The analytic process outlined by this module utilizes a modified grounded theory approach, which incorporates the tenets of Grounded Theory while remaining cognizant of recent debates in the literature  that contend researchers inevitably bring their prior theoretical stance or research experience to the research process (Boyatzis, 1998; Charmaz, 2000; Polkinghorne, 1995; Strauss & Corbin, 1998b).

We now have a better understanding of qualitative research, but there is still some debate among the team as to whether it is better to use qualitative methods or quantitative methods. 

To say that one approach is “better” than the other is misleading. Qualitative and quantitative research approaches are perhaps better thought of as two sides of the same coin.

Your team concludes that, rather than pitting either of these approaches “against” one another, the most benefits can be accrued from a mixed-methods design. A mixed methods study “involves the collection or analysis of both quantitative and/or qualitative data in a single study in which data are collected concurrently or sequentially, are given a priority, and involve the integration of the data in one or more stages in the process of research.” (Handbook of Mixed Methods Research).

The benefits of mixed designs include:
* The opportunity to examine different facets of a phenomenon
* The ability to maximize the strengths and minimize the limitations of each method
* An increase in stakeholder confidence in the overall findings

To conclude your discussion, you and the team review the differences between qualitative and quantitative approaches.
You are now ready to begin planning your study.

Only a sample or a subset of the population of interest is selected for study.  The study’s research objectives and the characteristics of the population (such as size and accessibility) determine which and how many individuals to select. 

Let’s discuss the most common sampling methods used in qualitative research. The descriptions in the table below will help you understand the reasons for using each method and its applicability to the current study.

Typically in qualitative projects, non-probability or non-random techniques are used to generate the sample. Non-probability refers to techniques that are not used to infer from the sample to the larger population.

The team agreed that a grounded theory tradition is most appropriate for this investigation because it seeks to examine the core social processes that guide behavior. Here are the key tenets of the tradition, as outlined by Glaser and Straus:

This section was an introduction to the fundamental characteristics of qualitative research. We reviewed the major traditions of qualitative research in public health, compared and contrasted qualitative and quantitative methods, and framed grounded theory as an ideal approach for the current investigation. The next section will discuss the data collection tasks and procedures typically undertaken in a qualitative study.

During the planning stages of qualitative data collection, you are gearing up for the exciting task of collecting the perceptions and feelings of young people on a very focused research topic. Key questions to consider include: 

* Who will be recruited for the groups? 
* Where will you hold the groups? 
* What questions will you ask during the during the group? 
* Who will facilitate the groups? 
* Will your focus groups be recorded? 

As with many aspects of the qualitative research process, there are no “right” or “wrong” answers. The guidance offered in this section should be adapted to reflect the real-world constraints of your project. How you manage the process of data collection will depend on time frame, money, and other related project resources. 

Let’s review some useful strategies to ensure a successful focus group.

### Establish a sampling criteria ###

Sampling was covered in the previous section of this module and it is an important consideration during the data collection planning phase.  A good rule of thumb is to conduct at least two groups with each segment of your population, based on key characteristics. For example, you may determine that the key characteristics of your population HIV positive youth are length of time since diagnosis, gender,or type and number of medications currently prescribed. . Accordingly your study might recruit two groups each of participants who are both newly diagnosed and who have been diagnosed for several years. You may also recruit for 2 male groups and 2 female groups. The unit of analysis is another consideration that should play a role in this decision (e.g. you may want to speak only with youth who have attended the adolescent clinic for 6 months or more).  

### Select a “key” location ###

The location where the groups are held can make or break your ability to get participants to show up for your focus groups. A convenient location for participants should be selected. For example, 

* Since our study will be talking with young participants in an urban area you may want to choose a location that easy to access by public transportation.  
* The sensitive nature of the topics under study also requires careful consideration of the acoustics of the room—can passersby easily eavesdrop on your conversation? If so, this may not be an ideal selection. 
* If you are holding your groups at the clinic where youth receive services, they may not feel free to discuss openly or honestly topics that portray providers in a negative light. In this instance, it may be better to hold the groups in an off site location. 
* You may also want to consider the acoustics of the room where the groups will be held. Is there construction planned nearby? This is of particular concern if you are audio-taping the groups as background noise can often drown out the words of respondents being recorded, which could result in difficulties during the analysis phases of your study.      

### Ensure that your moderator has “key” qualities ###

Moderators should remain neutral and non-judgmental in the face of confidential information and possess the capacity to be sensitive to feelings that are being experienced by respondents. As Boyatzis has noted, “with certain sources of information, competencies like empathy and social objectivity are crucial to perceiving patterns in a person’s life.”  Some studies have shown that especially for young people, race and gender matching the moderator to the characteristics of the population can help facilitate the flow of conversation and accuracy and quality of information provided by respondents. The best moderator is one that is skilled at active listening and can maintain a focused control of the group.    

### Develop the question guide ###

Here are several questions to consider in developing your guide: What are the ultimate goals of the study?  What issues does the study intend to illuminate and what practices will it influence? Why do you want to conduct it and why should we care about the results (i.e. is it worth doing)? Ideally, a focus group guide is developed in a team environment with a work product that is refined several times over. Adapted from McQueen’s (1998) guidance on team based codebook development, the following steps may be utilized in your development of a focus group guide in a team setting: 

* Assign primary responsibility for creating, revising focus group guide to one person 
* When generating questions, each team member should generate several variations on one theme (e.g. how the same question may be asked differently to capture the same responses)
* Schedule regular meetings to review questions 
* Discard questions that don’t work
* Accept that questions will need to be revised as data collection commences

**Obtain consent**

Perhaps the single most important consideration in collection of qualitative information is the adherence to ethical standards set forth by the IRB, or Institutional Review Board form who you have received permission to carry out the investigation. You should obtain verbal and written consent for participation from your respondents before the group begins.

**Record the group**

There are several advantages to recording your focus group as it takes place. Experienced focus group moderators recognize that they cannot focus their attention on the structured conversation they are leading while simultaneously writing down the verbatim statements of participants. Recording can save time during the groups by allowing the moderator to actively focus on what is being said. Moreover, audio recording the groups will increase the likelihood that no statements by respondents are missed. A good rule of thumb is to have two recorders, just in case one of the recorders fails. Typically the focus group guide will build in “warm up questions” or “ice breakers” to put respondents who seem wary of being recorded at ease. 

**Revise your guide as necessary**

As described in part one of this module, one of the strengths of qualitative research design is the inherent design flexibility. This allows for new topics previously unconsidered to be interrogated by the moderator. For example, perhaps youth across groups have been describing the similar challenges to medication adherence, like “not liking the taste of meds.” You may to decide to add new questions about a different barrier to adherence reported in fewer groups having reached “saturation” on this topic. Revising the guide does not only mean adding new questions—it may require that you reorder how your questions are delivered. Perhaps you are ending the group on a sour note by asking “What is the most stressful thing about living with HIV?” Participants may feel sad or alienated by a question like this, so the timing of such a question is key. Placing a difficult question at the middle of the guide and asking closing questions with a hopeful or optimistic tone like “What advice would you give to other HIV positive teens your age?“ may help respondents to “focus on the good” at the end of the focus group instead.

### Transcribe and/or review the data ###

In an ideal world, transcribing the audio tapes could provide several advantages for the analysis process, particularly where the analysis process is facilitated by a computer assisted qualitative data analysis software like ATLAS.ti. However, transcriptions costs can be one of the most expensive line items on a focus groups study budget. If cost prohibits transcription, listening to the tapes can be just as effective, albeit more time consuming and in some instances, tedious.

### Identify patterns and themes among and across participants ###

The processes and techniques involved in the analysis of qualitative data will be described in much further detail during the next section. However, at this juncture it is important to note that an important feature of this process is data reduction. A typical focus group lasting 90 minutes can produce as many as 100 pages! Therefore, during the analysis process the researcher is tasked with reducing this voluminous data to meaningful findings. The approach utilized in this module involves grouping themes into codes to classify the data and then noting patterns between the classifications of data. For example, you might notice a pattern that young respondents who have not disclosed their status consistently reporting barriers to medication adherence being a “fear of their status being discovered.” During later phases of the analysis, this pattern could be indicative of a larger theme of persistent HIV stigma in the lives of young people despite significant advances in the medical treatment of the disease.

The purpose of this section was to provide you with an overview of the typical tasks involved in a qualitative study. Three distinct design phases were discussed: Plan, Collect, and Analyze. Two important steps during your Plan phase are to establish a sampling criterion and to select a private, easily accessible location to conduct the groups. In the Collect phase, audio recording the groups is key and can eliminate missing data, when used properly. Finally, the Analyze phase generally involves identifying patterns and themes across groups and writing up these themes in a report or article. There are many more steps involved in analysis; these detailed steps are described in the next section.

In this section, you will be guided through the basic steps of the analysis process: Organize, Reduce, and Describe. An interactive practice exercise accompanies each step. Following this discussion, ATLAS.ti is introduced as a computer assisted software package that can supplement and improve pen and paper coding processes. Users follow instructional videos to learn how to use ATLAS.ti to manage large bodies of textual, graphical, audio, and video data.
Let’s go a bit deeper into each of these steps in the analysis process. Start the analysis process by organizing your data.

Your margin notes and initial or open codes have been tracked on the paper copies of your transcript but keeping an inventory or log of these items is useful. Since the number of codes can accumulate quickly and change as analysis progresses, it is advised that you keep a record of your emergent codes in a codebook; a great place to store the codebook is in the Atlas.TI’s Code Manager. Maintaining this list also provides an analytic opportunity to organize and reorganize the codes into major categories and subcategories (Saldana 2005). Code manuals or codebooks become especially critical when multiple team members work together on the same project data. By creating a codebook and requiring that all team members use the codebook when coding, you can ensure a level of standardization on how different people interpret and assign codes. 

The standard elements of a codebook include:

* Code name
* Code Definition
* A description of when to use the code
* A description of when not to use the code
* An example of a block of coded text

Here is a sample codebook using the codes from the previous exercise.

Begin the organization process by becoming very familiar with the data. This is accomplished through several types of readings: literal, interpretative, and reflexive. 

**Literal readings** of a transcript may take into account things like spelling or grammar issues in your transcripts, pauses, agreements or disagreements in a conversation, or laughter. It might also include descriptive data, such as whether a respondent has children or not, marital status, and so on. A literal reading allows the analyst to become familiar with the structure and content of the transcript. 

**Reflexive readings** reflect upon how the researcher played a role in the interview.  Reflexivity is an attitude of attending systematically to the effect of the researcher at every step of the research process (Robert Wood Johnson Foundation).  Malterud offers this on the topic of reflectivity in the analysis process: “A researcher's background and position will affect what they choose to investigate, the angle of investigation, the methods judged most adequate for this purpose, the findings considered most appropriate, and the framing and communication of conclusions” (Malterud, 2001, p. 483-484). Reflexive reading can promote a critical engagement and awareness of subjectivity and bias through transcript reading process. 

**Interpretive readings** are perhaps the most crucial type of reading an analyst will conduct. Interpreting is the ability to think abstractly, see patterns, and interrogate emerging patterns. Interpretation is involved in both data collection and data analysis, so the process is iterative. Ultimately analysts complete different types of interpretive readings to inform later analytic tasks like defining concepts, creating codes, and finding associations.

Jot down comments that reflect your thoughts on each type of reading. Imagine you are the moderator. You should have at least one note per type of reading (e.g., at least one note from your literal reading, one note from your interpretative reading, and one from your reflexive reading). The first one has been completed for you.

**MODERATOR:** Okay, so it's like mostly, you know, central Bruekleynville like general kind of area.  Okay.  And what kind of, what kind of techniques do you use to do outreach and education? 

A **literal** reading of this excerpt might read:   “Update spelling of Brooklynville in transcripts”

Now continue reading and commenting on this transcript.

As you are reading through the data in ATLAS.ti you may want to highlight certain segments of the primary document that you consider interesting or important. This is done by creating quotations. The following video describes how to make text selections and define them as quotations.

### Creating Quotations ###

Margin notes are a useful and foundational analytic tool that can be viewed as a dialogue with yourself about the data you are reading. You might think of margin notes as “scribbles” or “jottings” that will lay an analytic foundation for topics or themes of interest during the later phases of your analysis. 

Types of margin notes will vary from project to project but may include

* Your / the  researcher’s relationship with participants 
* Second thoughts about what a participant was “really” saying
* Doubts about data quality
* A new hypothesis that might explain a puzzling observation
* A mental note to pursue an issue further

* Explanatory and descriptive texts associated with other "objects", such as quotations, codes, etc
* A place to store/take methodological notes
* As a "bulletin board" in team projects
* A location for code lists or ideas

You can create free memos, meaning memos that are not linked to any quotations or codes, or memos that are  linked to data.

In the simplest terms, codes are meaningful labels applied to blocks of text so that they can easily be retrieved at a later stage for further comparison and analysis. 

Codes are given meaningful names that are relevant to the idea or topic under investigation. The process of coding (linking conceptually meaningful labels to text) involves close reading of the text. As new themes are identified from the data, new codes are created.

The list of codes will grow as new topics are identified. A running list of these codes is generally recorded in a code manual. As codes are meaningful ways of classifying the data, they can be developed in several ways including “a priori,” “in vivo,” or from your own invention. 

A priori codes may be identified from a range of sources like previous research or theory.  “In vivo” is Latin for "within the living" and refers to codes that are derived from participants’ terminology that captures meanings or experiences in their own terms. 

Codes developed from your own invention are generally those codes that are grounded in the concepts that emerge from your transcript readings are not drawn from pre-existing research.  

Let’s take a look at the different types of codes you can generate.

Creating codes typically requires several iterations of trial and error to decide which codes will be used and which codes will be discarded. The coding process consists of three main phases, or types of coding, each of which builds upon the work of the previous step.

Once a coding scheme is finalized, to the extent that any coding scheme is “final,” the researcher will then assign codes to the entire data set (i.e., you have to stop building a coding scheme at some point to complete the task of coding).

Let’s keep these questions in mind as we review different research designs for outcome evaluation.

There are many kinds of research designs to choose from. They range from the “gold standard” experimental design of randomized controlled trial to many kinds of quasi-experimental and descriptive designs. Some designs include comparison groups (not randomly assigned), and others might do pre and post-tests with just one group. Generally, we want to aim for the most rigorous research design that is possible in the given evaluation situation. 

Every situation presents with different constraints. For example, sometimes there is no way to randomly assign participants into intervention and control groups. Other times, the intervention has started already, and baseline measures cannot be collected. And in some cases, there are no suitable comparison groups, or the evaluation budget may only allow pre and post-tests on one group.

The two rows represent the two groups. The Rs indicate that the groups are randomly assigned. The Os indicate when outcomes are measured. In this case, both groups provide a baseline measure and a post-test. Note that only the first group has an X, which means that they are exposed to the intervention.

Is it possible to have randomly assigned groups in our ShapeTracker evaluation?
Randomized designs are not possible in most evaluations. As an alternative, there are many different kinds of quasi-experimental designs that vary in terms of rigor. Here are some examples:

The two groups are not randomly assigned, as indicated by the NR (Not Random). The second group is a comparison group. For example, we might be able to use half of the county, or a neighboring county, as a comparison group for our evaluation. Or maybe we give access to ShapeTracker to a group of Middleton county residents and then find a comparison group of other Middleton county residents with comparable demographic characteristics.

We can also add more outcome observation points to enhance the design.

For example, the first post-test could be after 3 months of using ShapeTracker, and then we could survey the users again at 6 months and 12 months, as indicated by the additional Os in the diagram. The comparison group has the same schedule of outcome measures but no intervention.

If it is too late, or otherwise impossible, to get a baseline measure of the outcome, the design would look like this:
Or, if a comparison group cannot be identified, the design would look like this:

This is a one-group pre-post design, with two additional follow-up measures of the outcome. Here we would be only assessing ShapeTraker users and whether their outcomes change over time. This type of design has limited validity because improvement over time can be due to factors other than the intervention.

If you cannot have a comparison group or a baseline, you are left with a very weak design of one-group, post-test only:

I’ll walk you through this first example.

Our team is considering a design that uses our neighbor county, Upperton, as a comparison group. We want to aggressively market ShapeTracker to everyone in our county, and we hope a high proportion of Middleton residents will sign up. We do not think we can find a comparable comparison group within Middleton county. 

We will utilize annual representative household surveys in both counties as an opportunity to collect data for this evaluation. We’ll add our outcome measures of physical activity, healthy eating and self-monitoring to these surveys. This year’s annual surveys, which will be collected before ShapeTracker is launched later this year, will be the baseline. Next year we will collect the same measures again in both counties. And for Middleton county household survey respondents who are using ShapeTracker, we’ll be able to include an additional section in the survey to collect some data we need for our process evaluation.

This is where we will create the notation for the design.

This is a comparison group design with baselines and post-tests for both groups (Middleton and Upperton). If we see more positive change from baseline to post-test in Middleton, compared to Upperton, we have evidence that ShapeTracker (the X) is having an impact on the outcomes.

### A Note about Qualitative and Mixed Methods ###

Outcome evaluation research typically uses quantitative methods, as is the case with our examples so far. Qualitative and mixed methods are mostly used in process evaluation, but they can also be useful in outcome evaluation. 

For example, let’s consider our evaluation question whether ShapeTracker decreases perceived barriers to physical activity and healthy eating. We may not have a clear idea of what specific barriers are important in our community and how ShapeTracker can address them. Qualitative methods may be well justified for this evaluation question. 

An example of evaluation design would be focus groups with ShapeTracker users to discuss challenges to exercising and eating healthy and how ShapeTracker has helped them. Systematic qualitative analysis can be used to provide evidence of program effectiveness.

### How do we choose among the many options for research design? ###

There are many factors to consider. Choosing a design is always a matter of finding the right balance of scientific rigor and feasibility. We will come back to specific threats to validity and feasibility considerations when we discuss the Limitations and Feasibility section of the Evaluation Plan.

It is also important to work with the stakeholders as we make decisions about the evaluation design. Please click on the stakeholder icon to remind yourself who is in our stakeholder advisory group.

And remember that the logic model and evaluation questions can help us stay focused as we discuss design options.

After considering many options, our team has selected a research design for the outcome evaluation. It builds on one of the examples discussed above. We don’t think randomization within Middleton county will work, or that we can find a comparison group within Middleton county. We have decided to work with our neighboring county, Upperton, to get a comparison group for our evaluation. This will allow us to aggressively market ShapeTracker to all residents of Middleton county. Luckily, Upperton and Middleton are very similar in size and population demographics, including smart phone use and obesity, and both counties conduct annual representative household surveys.

To strengthen our design, we will take advantage of the annual surveys and include two post measures, one year after baseline and two years after baseline. In other words, our outcome measures will be administered in three consecutive annual household surveys in both counties.

Earlier, we located one of the outcomes – self-monitoring of healthy eating and physical activity – in the short-term outcome column. The corresponding evaluation question is: “Does use of ShapeTracker increase self-monitoring of healthy eating and physical activity?”

Our primary outcome evaluation question is: “Does use of ShapeTracker increase healthy eating and physical activity among county residents?” In light of our newly defined research design, we should specify:

“Do residents of Middleton county who use ShapeTracker increase healthy eating and physical activity, compared to residents of Upperton county with no access to ShapeTracker?”

Given the type of outcomes we chose, we have a good chance of finding validated measures that are appropriate for our survey. The validated measures can help us define measurable indicators of our outcomes. The validated scales will be incorporated into our annual household surveys.

Instrument Design
Design of the data collection instruments, whether they are surveys, interview questions, or something else, is often a big evaluation task. Stakeholder input is very important and helpful during instrument design.

Sampling
Evaluators also need to define their sampling strategies and sample size requirements. For our primary outcome evaluation design, we are lucky to have access to county-wide household surveys that are designed to reach representative samples of county residents.

Major types of sampling strategies include [definitions to be added]:

* Simple random sampling
* Stratified random sampling
* Cluster sampling
* Convenience sampling
* Snowball sampling

A power analysis can be conducted to calculate a required sample size for an evaluation. Many tools are available for sample size calculations, although they require some understanding of the principles of statistical inference. This is an area where many evaluators reach out to biostatisticians for help.

A final note about the Evaluation Design section: It is also important to have clear written protocols for data collection activities. These may need to be separate documents outside of the Evaluation Plan. They will list all steps that need to be carried out with each data collection activity, including instructions for recruitment and informed consent.

You have probably heard the technical terminology of validity used in discussions about research designs. To be precise, validity is about how true or correct the inferences are that you can make based on your design. Things like adequate sample size and randomized control group will increase the validity of your design.

“Threats to validity are specific reasons why we can be partly or completely wrong.” (Shadish, Cook & Campbell)

How does a researcher know when to use a qualitative approach and when to use a quantitative approach to a study? Is one approach really better than the other?
 
A choice between research methods rests fundamentally on a set of decisions about the questions a researcher wants to answer and the practicality of gathering the kind of data that will answer those questions. In this first part, we will explore the differences between the different research traditions. 

* Compare and contrast the qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods traditions to research design in public health
* Select an appropriate sampling strategy based on study design
* Summarize the key ethical considerations when engaging in human subjects research

Throughout this module we will use real-world examples and you will take on the role of the lead researcher.
This issue raises multiple research questions that could guide the intervention design, so you decide to review the existing data before formulating your research questions.

According to recent data from the Brooklynville Department of Health, the racial and ethnic disparities reported at the national level are also seen in the Brooklynville community. Black and Hispanic youth in Brooklynville account for a disproportionate number of new HIV diagnoses. In 2010, Black and Hispanic youth represented close to 75% of new HIV cases. The numbers also show that Brooklynville has a disproportionate number of HIV and AIDS cases in youth, compared to the rest of the United States. For example, although youth between the ages of 13 and 24 represent only 3% of the population, they account for roughly 14% of AIDS cases in Brooklynville.

These statistics concern you. Additionally, you conclude after reviewing the literature that most of the evidence-based interventions reported appear to be focused on HIV-prevention; few studies provide guidance on the kind of interventions that are effective for youth once they are diagnosed.

One of the primary reasons you determined that a qualitative study was right for your team’s investigation is because you know that qualitative methods allow researchers to understand the processes by which events and actions take place. 

A major strength of qualitative studies is their ability to get at the processes that lead to behaviors or outcomes, processes that survey research is often very poor at identifying.

###Key features of Qualitative Research###

1. **Generates a narrative**: Typically, qualitative research generates text or narrative (i.e., non-numerical) data that requires interpretative analysis. Text or narrative data can be come from a variety of sources including individual interviews, focus groups, or written responses from open-ended questions on a survey. Analyzing and interpreting textual data is an iterative process that begins during data collection and often continues throughout the later phases of the study.
2. **Direct contact with participants**: During data collection researchers will engage with research participants. Methods like in-depth interviews or focus groups whereby the researcher is the instrument of data collection provide the study participants with an opportunity to express their thoughts and feelings in their own words, to a skilled researcher who is attentive and actively listening. 
3. **Design flexibility**: Design flexibility allows researchers to adapt the research design as situations change or pursue new paths of discovery as they emerge. For example, during data collection you may reach “saturation” or a point when you are no longer hearing or seeing new information from your young respondents. Unlike quantitative researchers who wait until the end of the study to analyze their data, qualitative researchers often analyze their data throughout the study. The design flexibility inherent in qualitative designs allows you to pose new questions or follow up on previously unconsidered topics that your respondents might introduce during data collection. 

 But, is there only one way to approach qualitative research?

Qualitative research is often discussed as if it were one approach. However, qualitative research comes in many different varieties, or traditions:

1. Phenomenology
2. Ethnography
3. Grounded theory
4. Biography/narrative
5. Case study

The team decides to discuss three of the most common traditions and approaches used in the public health.

An exhaustive review of qualitative research traditions is beyond the scope of this module, however interested investigators may examine [Cresswell (2004)](http://www.amazon.com/Qualitative-Inquiry-Research-Design-Traditions/dp/0761901442) for a detailed discussion.

Phenomenology is the study of structures of consciousness as experienced from the first-person point of view. Studies developed in the phenomenological tradition are “directed to the participant’s experiences, feelings, beliefs and convictions about the theme in question” (Welman & Kruger, 1999, p. 196). Typically, the researcher reduces data gathered as lengthy interviews describing the shared experiences of several informants to a central meaning, or “essence” of the experience (McCaslin & Scott, 2003).

A qualitative project designed in a phenomenological tradition might pose questions like:

* What are the lived experiences of individuals in a given community?
* How does “stigma” impact the life of young people living with HIV? 
* What meanings do young people attach to an HIV diagnosis? 
* How do HIV-positive young people experience disclosure to their parents and sexual partners?

Ethnography is the study of cultures through close observation, reading, and interpretation. Ethnographic researchers work “in the field,” in the culture  they are studying. The activities they conduct are also often called fieldwork. Ethnographic researchers learn how to recognize traits that make up a culture and how to describe it to others; through direct and close participant observation researchers observe the differences between participants’ subjective reporting of what they believe and what they do (Creswell 1997).

A qualitative study designed from an ethnographic perspective might ask questions such as:

* What are the meanings that guide behavior?
* How is sexual desire is organized and interpreted in the lives of HIV-positive young women?
* What are the norms that guide risk behavior among homeless HIV-positive youth?

Grounded theory is a qualitative approach to generating and developing a theory from data that the researcher collects. As much as possible, the researcher should set aside theoretical ideas or notions so that the analytic, substantive theory can emerge. The primary outcome of this approach is a theory with specific components: a central phenomenon, causal conditions, strategies, conditions and context, and consequences (Corbin and Strauss 1990).

A qualitative study designed using a grounded theory approach might pose questions such as:
* What are the core social processes within a given social situation?
* What are the dynamics of hope and despair among young men who receive an HIV diagnosis? 
* How do HIV-positive youth manage their interacting illness symptoms, medication side effects, and treatment adherence choices?

The analytic process outlined by this module utilizes a modified grounded theory approach, which incorporates the tenets of Grounded Theory while remaining cognizant of recent debates in the literature  that contend researchers inevitably bring their prior theoretical stance or research experience to the research process (Boyatzis, 1998; Charmaz, 2000; Polkinghorne, 1995; Strauss & Corbin, 1998b).

We now have a better understanding of qualitative research, but there is still some debate among the team as to whether it is better to use qualitative methods or quantitative methods. 

To say that one approach is “better” than the other is misleading. Qualitative and quantitative research approaches are perhaps better thought of as two sides of the same coin.
Or, if a comparison group cannot be identified, the design would look like this:

Your team concludes that, rather than pitting either of these approaches “against” one another, the most benefits can be accrued from a mixed-methods design. A mixed methods study “involves the collection or analysis of both quantitative and/or qualitative data in a single study in which data are collected concurrently or sequentially, are given a priority, and involve the integration of the data in one or more stages in the process of research.” (Handbook of Mixed Methods Research).

The benefits of mixed designs include:
* The opportunity to examine different facets of a phenomenon
* The ability to maximize the strengths and minimize the limitations of each method
* An increase in stakeholder confidence in the overall findings

To conclude your discussion, you and the team review the differences between qualitative and quantitative approaches.
You are now ready to begin planning your study.

Only a sample or a subset of the population of interest is selected for study.  The study’s research objectives and the characteristics of the population (such as size and accessibility) determine which and how many individuals to select. 

Let’s discuss the most common sampling methods used in qualitative research. The descriptions in the table below will help you understand the reasons for using each method and its applicability to the current study.

Typically in qualitative projects, non-probability or non-random techniques are used to generate the sample. Non-probability refers to techniques that are not used to infer from the sample to the larger population.

How is our right to know balanced against the participants’ right to privacy, dignity, and self-determination?  - Miles and Huberman

The definition of a human subject is “a living individual about whom an investigator (whether professional or student) conducting research obtains data through intervention or interaction with the individual, or identifiable private information.” Private information can include names, addresses, or cell phone numbers.

The nature of ethical problems in qualitative research is different compared to problems in quantitative research. For example, potential ethical conflicts could arise when considering how a researcher gains access to a community group, the effects the researcher may have on participants, and the subjective biases that may arise during data collection.

This section was an introduction to the fundamental characteristics of qualitative research. We reviewed the major traditions of qualitative research in public health, compared and contrasted qualitative and quantitative methods, and framed grounded theory as an ideal approach for the current investigation. The next section will discuss the data collection tasks and procedures typically undertaken in a qualitative study.

The purpose of this section is to provide an overview of typical qualitative data collection techniques. A number of approaches can be used to collect data, but we will restrict our discussion to focus groups as these one of the most common qualitative methods in public health practice. Other methods, such as semi-structured interviews, observational techniques, and unobstrusive methods are beyond the scope of this module.

By the end of this section you will be able to:

* Describe the advantages and disadvantages of different qualitative research collection methods.
* Select appropriate collection methods for a given study design.
* Describe the steps necessary to conduct effective focus groups.
Let's begin with a comparison of the some of the most common methods used to collect data in qualitative research projects.

Let’s review where we are. 

The team decides to conduct a focus group with the youth in Brooklynville to discuss a number of topics relevant to the risk taking behaviors of HIV-positive youth, such as

* Access to care and quality of service delivery
* Barriers and facilitators to medication adherence, or 
* The role of social media in sexual risk networks. 

A focus group is a form of group interview used to guide, focus, and inform planning, and implementation of any activity and to ensure that the activities undertaken respond to the needs of primary stakeholders (PSF Project Resources 2006). 

Let’s review the steps in designing successful focus group.

During the planning stages of qualitative data collection, you are gearing up for the exciting task of collecting the perceptions and feelings of young people on a very focused research topic. Key questions to consider include: 

* Who will be recruited for the groups? 
* Where will you hold the groups? 
* What questions will you ask during the during the group? 
* Who will facilitate the groups? 
* Will your focus groups be recorded? 

As with many aspects of the qualitative research process, there are no “right” or “wrong” answers. The guidance offered in this section should be adapted to reflect the real-world constraints of your project. How you manage the process of data collection will depend on time frame, money, and other related project resources. 

Let’s review some useful strategies to ensure a successful focus group.

### Establish a sampling criteria ###

Sampling was covered in the previous section of this module and it is an important consideration during the data collection planning phase.  A good rule of thumb is to conduct at least two groups with each segment of your population, based on key characteristics. For example, you may determine that the key characteristics of your population HIV positive youth are length of time since diagnosis, gender,or type and number of medications currently prescribed. . Accordingly your study might recruit two groups each of participants who are both newly diagnosed and who have been diagnosed for several years. You may also recruit for 2 male groups and 2 female groups. The unit of analysis is another consideration that should play a role in this decision (e.g. you may want to speak only with youth who have attended the adolescent clinic for 6 months or more).  

### Select a “key” location ###

The location where the groups are held can make or break your ability to get participants to show up for your focus groups. A convenient location for participants should be selected. For example, 

* Since our study will be talking with young participants in an urban area you may want to choose a location that easy to access by public transportation.  
* The sensitive nature of the topics under study also requires careful consideration of the acoustics of the room—can passersby easily eavesdrop on your conversation? If so, this may not be an ideal selection. 
* If you are holding your groups at the clinic where youth receive services, they may not feel free to discuss openly or honestly topics that portray providers in a negative light. In this instance, it may be better to hold the groups in an off site location. 
* You may also want to consider the acoustics of the room where the groups will be held. Is there construction planned nearby? This is of particular concern if you are audio-taping the groups as background noise can often drown out the words of respondents being recorded, which could result in difficulties during the analysis phases of your study.      

### Ensure that your moderator has “key” qualities ###

Moderators should remain neutral and non-judgmental in the face of confidential information and possess the capacity to be sensitive to feelings that are being experienced by respondents. As Boyatzis has noted, “with certain sources of information, competencies like empathy and social objectivity are crucial to perceiving patterns in a person’s life.”  Some studies have shown that especially for young people, race and gender matching the moderator to the characteristics of the population can help facilitate the flow of conversation and accuracy and quality of information provided by respondents. The best moderator is one that is skilled at active listening and can maintain a focused control of the group.    

### Develop the question guide ###

Here are several questions to consider in developing your guide: What are the ultimate goals of the study?  What issues does the study intend to illuminate and what practices will it influence? Why do you want to conduct it and why should we care about the results (i.e. is it worth doing)? Ideally, a focus group guide is developed in a team environment with a work product that is refined several times over. Adapted from McQueen’s (1998) guidance on team based codebook development, the following steps may be utilized in your development of a focus group guide in a team setting: 

* Assign primary responsibility for creating, revising focus group guide to one person 
* When generating questions, each team member should generate several variations on one theme (e.g. how the same question may be asked differently to capture the same responses)
* Schedule regular meetings to review questions 
* Discard questions that don’t work
* Accept that questions will need to be revised as data collection commences

**Obtain consent**

Perhaps the single most important consideration in collection of qualitative information is the adherence to ethical standards set forth by the IRB, or Institutional Review Board form who you have received permission to carry out the investigation. You should obtain verbal and written consent for participation from your respondents before the group begins.

**Record the group**

There are several advantages to recording your focus group as it takes place. Experienced focus group moderators recognize that they cannot focus their attention on the structured conversation they are leading while simultaneously writing down the verbatim statements of participants. Recording can save time during the groups by allowing the moderator to actively focus on what is being said. Moreover, audio recording the groups will increase the likelihood that no statements by respondents are missed. A good rule of thumb is to have two recorders, just in case one of the recorders fails. Typically the focus group guide will build in “warm up questions” or “ice breakers” to put respondents who seem wary of being recorded at ease. 

**Revise your guide as necessary**

As described in part one of this module, one of the strengths of qualitative research design is the inherent design flexibility. This allows for new topics previously unconsidered to be interrogated by the moderator. For example, perhaps youth across groups have been describing the similar challenges to medication adherence, like “not liking the taste of meds.” You may to decide to add new questions about a different barrier to adherence reported in fewer groups having reached “saturation” on this topic. Revising the guide does not only mean adding new questions—it may require that you reorder how your questions are delivered. Perhaps you are ending the group on a sour note by asking “What is the most stressful thing about living with HIV?” Participants may feel sad or alienated by a question like this, so the timing of such a question is key. Placing a difficult question at the middle of the guide and asking closing questions with a hopeful or optimistic tone like “What advice would you give to other HIV positive teens your age?“ may help respondents to “focus on the good” at the end of the focus group instead.

### Transcribe and/or review the data ###

In an ideal world, transcribing the audio tapes could provide several advantages for the analysis process, particularly where the analysis process is facilitated by a computer assisted qualitative data analysis software like ATLAS.ti. However, transcriptions costs can be one of the most expensive line items on a focus groups study budget. If cost prohibits transcription, listening to the tapes can be just as effective, albeit more time consuming and in some instances, tedious.

### Identify patterns and themes among and across participants ###

The processes and techniques involved in the analysis of qualitative data will be described in much further detail during the next section. However, at this juncture it is important to note that an important feature of this process is data reduction. A typical focus group lasting 90 minutes can produce as many as 100 pages! Therefore, during the analysis process the researcher is tasked with reducing this voluminous data to meaningful findings. The approach utilized in this module involves grouping themes into codes to classify the data and then noting patterns between the classifications of data. For example, you might notice a pattern that young respondents who have not disclosed their status consistently reporting barriers to medication adherence being a “fear of their status being discovered.” During later phases of the analysis, this pattern could be indicative of a larger theme of persistent HIV stigma in the lives of young people despite significant advances in the medical treatment of the disease.

The purpose of this section was to provide you with an overview of the typical tasks involved in a qualitative study. Three distinct design phases were discussed: Plan, Collect, and Analyze. Two important steps during your Plan phase are to establish a sampling criterion and to select a private, easily accessible location to conduct the groups. In the Collect phase, audio recording the groups is key and can eliminate missing data, when used properly. Finally, the Analyze phase generally involves identifying patterns and themes across groups and writing up these themes in a report or article. There are many more steps involved in analysis; these detailed steps are described in the next section.

In this section, you will be guided through the basic steps of the analysis process: Organize, Reduce, and Describe. An interactive practice exercise accompanies each step. Following this discussion, ATLAS.ti is introduced as a computer assisted software package that can supplement and improve pen and paper coding processes. Users follow instructional videos to learn how to use ATLAS.ti to manage large bodies of textual, graphical, audio, and video data.
Let’s go a bit deeper into each of these steps in the analysis process. Start the analysis process by organizing your data.

Begin the organization process by becoming very familiar with the data. This is accomplished through several types of readings: literal, interpretative, and reflexive. 

**Literal readings** of a transcript may take into account things like spelling or grammar issues in your transcripts, pauses, agreements or disagreements in a conversation, or laughter. It might also include descriptive data, such as whether a respondent has children or not, marital status, and so on. A literal reading allows the analyst to become familiar with the structure and content of the transcript. 

**Reflexive readings** reflect upon how the researcher played a role in the interview.  Reflexivity is an attitude of attending systematically to the effect of the researcher at every step of the research process (Robert Wood Johnson Foundation).  Malterud offers this on the topic of reflectivity in the analysis process: “A researcher's background and position will affect what they choose to investigate, the angle of investigation, the methods judged most adequate for this purpose, the findings considered most appropriate, and the framing and communication of conclusions” (Malterud, 2001, p. 483-484). Reflexive reading can promote a critical engagement and awareness of subjectivity and bias through transcript reading process. 

**Interpretive readings** are perhaps the most crucial type of reading an analyst will conduct. Interpreting is the ability to think abstractly, see patterns, and interrogate emerging patterns. Interpretation is involved in both data collection and data analysis, so the process is iterative. Ultimately analysts complete different types of interpretive readings to inform later analytic tasks like defining concepts, creating codes, and finding associations.

### Creating Quotations ###

Margin notes are a useful and foundational analytic tool that can be viewed as a dialogue with yourself about the data you are reading. You might think of margin notes as “scribbles” or “jottings” that will lay an analytic foundation for topics or themes of interest during the later phases of your analysis. 

Types of margin notes will vary from project to project but may include

* Your / the  researcher’s relationship with participants 
* Second thoughts about what a participant was “really” saying
* Doubts about data quality
* A new hypothesis that might explain a puzzling observation
* A mental note to pursue an issue further

* Explanatory and descriptive texts associated with other "objects", such as quotations, codes, etc
* A place to store/take methodological notes
* As a "bulletin board" in team projects
* A location for code lists or ideas

You can create free memos, meaning memos that are not linked to any quotations or codes, or memos that are  linked to data.

In the simplest terms, codes are meaningful labels applied to blocks of text so that they can easily be retrieved at a later stage for further comparison and analysis. 

Codes are given meaningful names that are relevant to the idea or topic under investigation. The process of coding (linking conceptually meaningful labels to text) involves close reading of the text. As new themes are identified from the data, new codes are created.

The list of codes will grow as new topics are identified. A running list of these codes is generally recorded in a code manual. As codes are meaningful ways of classifying the data, they can be developed in several ways including “a priori,” “in vivo,” or from your own invention. 

A priori codes may be identified from a range of sources like previous research or theory.  “In vivo” is Latin for "within the living" and refers to codes that are derived from participants’ terminology that captures meanings or experiences in their own terms. 

Codes developed from your own invention are generally those codes that are grounded in the concepts that emerge from your transcript readings are not drawn from pre-existing research.  

Let’s take a look at the different types of codes you can generate.

Creating codes typically requires several iterations of trial and error to decide which codes will be used and which codes will be discarded. The coding process consists of three main phases, or types of coding, each of which builds upon the work of the previous step.

Once a coding scheme is finalized, to the extent that any coding scheme is “final,” the researcher will then assign codes to the entire data set (i.e., you have to stop building a coding scheme at some point to complete the task of coding).

Your margin notes and initial or open codes have been tracked on the paper copies of your transcript but keeping an inventory or log of these items is useful. Since the number of codes can accumulate quickly and change as analysis progresses, it is advised that you keep a record of your emergent codes in a codebook; a great place to store the codebook is in the Atlas.TI’s Code Manager. Maintaining this list also provides an analytic opportunity to organize and reorganize the codes into major categories and subcategories (Saldana 2005). Code manuals or codebooks become especially critical when multiple team members work together on the same project data. By creating a codebook and requiring that all team members use the codebook when coding, you can ensure a level of standardization on how different people interpret and assign codes. 

The standard elements of a codebook include:

* Code name
* Code Definition
* A description of when to use the code
* A description of when not to use the code
* An example of a block of coded text

Here is a sample codebook using the codes from the previous exercise.

Coding is an iterative process, often requiring several cycles. As you code additional transcripts, new themes and ways of thinking about your data are likely to emerge. This iterative process usually dictates that previously coded blocks of text will need to be uncoded and/or recoded, to check if there is any more data that should be coded as the newly created code.

It is important to apply all your codes to the whole data set because:

* Something you come across later on may change how you want to code the data
* You may not have noticed a new pattern in the data until you had coded a number of interviews 
* If you only code the data units after you created the code, any previously coded data units will not be included in the searches involving this code; this will be especially important in later phases of analysis when using the ATLAS software.

A critical first step in the analysis of qualitative data involves getting to know your data through several types of reading, followed by an iterative process of coding and categorizing chunks of that data into themes. Qualitative data, including focus group transcripts, can generate tens or hundreds of pages of information. Coding is one way of tracking and managing the volumes of information. There are several computer assisted software packages that can supplement and improve pen and paper coding processes. This section introduced ATLAS.ti, a powerful workbench for managing large bodies of textual, graphical, audio, and video data.

* Apply previous knowledge of stakeholders, program logic and evaluation questions to the design of a comprehensive evaluation plan.
* Assess advantages and limitations of evaluation designs, including randomized, quasi-experimental, pre-post, qualitative, and mixed methods designs.
* Appraise and compare options for data collection methods, indicators, measures and sampling strategies.
* Identify and address threats to validity.

The purpose of this section was to provide you with an overview of the typical tasks involved in a qualitative study. Three distinct design phases were discussed: Plan, Collect, and Analyze. Two important steps during your Plan phase are to establish a sampling criterion and to select a private, easily accessible location to conduct the groups. In the Collect phase, audio recording the groups is key and can eliminate missing data, when used properly. Finally, the Analyze phase generally involves identifying patterns and themes across groups and writing up these themes in a report or article. There are many more steps involved in analysis; these detailed steps are described in the next section.

Hi, I’m Sally and I work at the Middleton County Health Department. Today, I could really use your help with this evaluation plan I’m working on.

About six months ago, my Commissioner came back from a meeting at the CDC all excited about this new CDC-sponsored smartphone app that a few local health departments out in California have disseminated into their communities with great success. It’s called ShapeTracker, and apparently, people love it. I was tasked with launching this app in our county.

ShapeTracker is a very comprehensive, well-designed, and user-friendly diet and fitness app that features local resources. People use it on their smartphones to track their diet and exercise and to connect to wellness resources in the community. The app is designed to work on all different kinds of smart phones and is very promising because so many people have become regular active users in the pilot communities.

Obesity prevention is a high priority in our health department’s latest strategic plan and the ShapeTracker program is the biggest new obesity initiative we are rolling out. Here are some of the stats we put together on obesity, and also on smartphone use.

* 38% of adults in Middleton County are obese
* 67% of adults in Middleton County are overweight or obese
* The rates of obesity and overweight in Middleton county are higher than the national and state averages
* Nationally, 46% of adults have smartphones
* According to the most recent household survey, 51% of adults in Middleton County have smartphones

We have made a lot of progress with setting up this program in Middleton County, and right now we are finishing the process of compiling the list of local county resources and we are customizing the app with that information. We have started testing it among some health department employees and so far they seem to really like it.

We want to do a comprehensive evaluation of the ShapeTracker program, and we are trying to apply the CDC six-step Program Evaluation Framework. I formed a small advisory group of stakeholders, and together we have already put together a logic model and started drafting some evaluation questions. With this kind of new program, which has its skeptics, it’s really important to show whether it is making a positive difference. 

I know we are doing the right things with our evaluation planning so far, but we still have to figure out all the technical parts of the research design. We are so happy to have you on our team to help us work on that. In a few minutes I’ll fill you in on what we’ve come up with so far.

Our evaluation plan is based on the CDC Program Evaluation Framework, so lets review that first.

The CDC Program Evaluation has six steps. With your mouse, hover over each step in the process and each of the four standards for more information. 

In this module, we will focus primarily on the steps entitled "Focus no the Evaluation Design" and "Gather Credible Evidence."

Let’s keep these questions in mind as we review different research designs for outcome evaluation.

There are many kinds of research designs to choose from. They range from the “gold standard” experimental design of randomized controlled trial to many kinds of quasi-experimental and descriptive designs. Some designs include comparison groups (not randomly assigned), and others might do pre and post-tests with just one group. Generally, we want to aim for the most rigorous research design that is possible in the given the time, resources and data available. 

Every situation presents with different constraints. For example, sometimes there is no way to randomly assign participants into intervention and control groups. Other times, the intervention has started already, and baseline measures cannot be collected. And in some cases, there are no suitable comparison groups, or the evaluation budget may only allow pre and post-tests on one group.

The two rows represent the two groups. The Rs indicate that the groups are randomly assigned. The Os indicate when outcomes are measured. In this case, both groups provide a baseline measure and a post-test. Note that only the first group has an X, which means that they are exposed to the intervention.
Randomized designs are not possible in most evaluations. As an alternative, there are many different kinds of quasi-experimental designs that vary in terms of rigor. Here are some examples:

The two groups are not randomly assigned, as indicated by the NR (Not Random). The second group is a comparison group. For example, we might be able to use half of the county, or a neighboring county, as a comparison group for our evaluation. Or maybe we give access to ShapeTracker to a group of Middleton county residents and then find a comparison group of other Middleton county residents with comparable demographic characteristics.

We can also add more outcome observation points to enhance the design.

For example, the first post-test could be after 3 months of using ShapeTracker, and then we could survey the users again at 6 months and 12 months, as indicated by the additional Os in the diagram. The comparison group has the same schedule of outcome measures but no intervention.

This type of design has limited validity because improvement over time can be due to factors other than the intervention.

If you cannot have a comparison group or a baseline, you are left with a very weak design of one-group, post-test only:
